chapter.title: Categories of setting accommodations
chapter.content:
The fourth accommodation we will discuss is setting. Setting accommodations refer to changes to the location in which a student receives instruction or takes a test. Setting accommodations may also mean modifying the conditions of an instructional or testing setting. 

Setting accommodations benefit students who are easily distracted or who concentrate best in small group or individual settings. A setting accommodation may reduce distractions by allowing a student to do individual work in a different location, usually in a place with few or no other students.

There are four general categories of setting accommodations that allow the student to focus better on classroom tasks and tests:

  1. Moving the student to a different seat within in the classroom;
  2. Moving the student to a private room
  3. Moving the student to a quiet room, or
  4. Allowing the student to participate in a small group setting.

Students who might perform better when they can read aloud or make noises that distract other students may benefit from the occasional use of individual learning settings.

chapter.title: Examples of setting accommodations
chapter.content:
Consider Derek, an adult learner who can be easily distracted in a classroom environment if he is sitting near doors, windows, etc. Derek finds it easier to concentrate if he is sitting in a physically enclosed space with little visual stimuli. He operates most effectively if no other individuals are present in the room.
